#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Choose a Hospital for Surgery
#Text=Finding the right hospital for surgery can be a complicated task .
#Text=You should first consult with your primary care doctor and your insurance provider to determine which surgeons and facilities will meet your needs .
#Text=Then you should review the different hospitals , looking at patient reviews and examining data on things like success and complication rates .
#Text=Finally , you should consult with different surgeons and talk with them about the procedure and if there are any alternative treatments .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Getting the Basics
#Text=Talk with your doctor .
#Text=The first step in finding a surgeon and location for your operation is talking with your primary care provider .
#Text=You may need your primary care doctor to write you a referral to a surgeon .
#Text=They will likely recommend surgeons and hospitals that they have worked with in the past .
#Text=Often , your choice of surgeon will determine your choice of hospital .
#Text=When you are talking to your doctor , ask things like “ Who would you recommend as a surgeon ? ” and “ What hospital do you recommend ? ”
#Text=Check with your insurer .
#Text=After you consult your doctor , you should contact your insurer .
#Text=Unless you are willing to pay out-of-pocket for the surgery , you will need to make sure that any surgeon and you go to is in-network .
#Text=Depending on the surgery , an out-of-network operation may end up costing you thousands of dollars .
#Text=When you talk to your insurer , ask questions like “ What specialists are covered by my insurance ? ” and “ Is this surgeon in-network ? ”
#Text=Look for hospitals that have expertise in treating your condition .
#Text=To get the best care , you will want to go to a hospital that has a reputation for treating your condition .
#Text=General hospitals are great for routine operations like hernias or gallbladder surgery .
#Text=However , you may need a specialty hospital if you need something like heart bypass or reconstructive surgery .
#Text=Talk with your primary care provider and your insurer to find the facility that meets your needs and is affordable .
#Text=Make sure that your surgeon has the ability to admit patients at the hospital you are considering .
#Text=Hospitals that perform many of the same types of procedures tend to have higher success rates .
#Text=Finding the Right Hospital
#Text=Review
#Text=hospital ratings .
#Text=There are a number of nonprofit and government organizations that collect and publish hospital reviews and ratings .
#Text=You can look up reviews of specific hospitals through groups like Consumer Reports and Hospital Compare .
#Text=Try to find facilities that received good reviews and have a high success rate for the procedure you need .
#Text=Many states and consumer groups give health care facilities report cards that highlight their strengths and weaknesses .
#Text=Try checking out http://www.leapfroggroup.org/ for data on quality and safety of procedures in hospitals throughout the U.S.
#Text=Examine the data .
#Text=When you are reviewing hospital information , be sure to look at data about infection rates , readmission , and death .
#Text=Avoid hospitals where there are high rates of infection or where patients are readmitted soon after the are discharged .
#Text=In addition , you should check the mortality rate of each hospital .
#Text=These numbers are good indicators of the quality of care that you might expect in that facility .
#Text=Look for the “ outcome studies ” published by the different facilities .
#Text=These studies will let you know how well patients do after having certain types of procedures .
#Text=You can often find these published by nonprofit or government groups .
#Text=Visit the hospitals .
#Text=Take some time to visit each facility that you are considering .
#Text=Check out the hospital and make sure that it looks and smells clean .
#Text=If a hospital seems run down , you might want to look into other facilities .
#Text=It ’s also important for the staff to be friendly and approachable .
#Text=Pay attention to how hospital employees respond to you when you visit .
#Text=Many facilities allow you to schedule a tour .
#Text=To save some time , you should schedule a tour after your surgical consults .
#Text=Think about location .
#Text=Depending on where you live , you might need to travel for your surgery .
#Text=This could be because where you live does not have the facilities or the staff to perform your procedure .
#Text=You might also travel in order to have your surgery done by a renowned surgeon at a particular facility .
#Text=However , you might also choose to stay local in order to have your family and friends near .
#Text=Think about what your expectations are for the surgery and whether or not you are willing to travel for it .
#Text=Choosing the Right Surgeon
#Text=Review their credentials .
#Text=Look for a surgeon that has the necessary training to perform the operation you need .
#Text=You want a specialist certified by the American Board of Medical Specialties .
#Text=This tells you that they received a degree from a qualified medical school , completed their residency , is licensed by a state medical board , and passed at least on ABMS exam .
#Text=You can check the qualifications of your doctor by going to certificationmatters.org.
#Text=Look for red flags .
#Text=Check with your state medical board to see if your surgeon has had any malpractice claims or disciplinary actions .
#Text=Although most surgeons are sued once or twice , a specialist who has been sued multiple times may be problematic .
#Text=In addition , multiple disciplinary actions may be an indication of substance abuse or a behavioral issue .
#Text=Meet with the surgeon .
#Text=Once you have narrowed down your options , you should schedule some consultations with various surgeons .
#Text=Talk with them about their success and complication rates when performing your operation , and ask them how many of this type of procedure they have performed .
#Text=You should also talk with them about their attitudes on an alternative to surgery .
#Text=Finally , it is important to get a feel for whether you trust this person .
#Text=Listen to your gut and determine if you are comfortable with this person potentially having your life in their hands .
#Text=A doctor who is confident in their ability and has a solid track record will be willing to discuss their success rate with you .
#Text=You should ask your surgeon things like “ What is your success rate with this procedure ? ” and “ Do you recommend any alternatives to surgery ? ”
